com.sri.ai.grinder.api

Interface SingleVariableConstraint

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>, Constraint, Expression, java.io.Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractSingleVariableConstraint, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtomsIncludingEquality, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithDependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithIndependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableNumericConstraint, SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms, SingleVariableDifferenceArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariableEqualityConstraint, SingleVariableLinearRealArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariablePropositionalConstraint

    public interface SingleVariableConstraint
extends Constraint
    An Expression with efficient internal representation for incrementally deciding satisfiability of a boolean formulas on literals in a certain theory.
    Author:
    braz

    • Method Detail

      • getVariable

        Expression getVariable()
        Returns:
        the variable term constrained by this constraint.

      • getExternalLiterals

        java.util.List<Expression> getExternalLiterals()
        A single-variable constraint has the ability to temporarily hold literals not on its variable. This returns such literals. This works as a buffer for literals propagated (deduced) at the point in which the constraint is formed (by conjunction with another), so that they don't need to be deduced every time we need to check if there are literals to be propagated.
        Returns:

      • makeSimplificationWithoutExternalLiterals

        SingleVariableConstraint makeSimplificationWithoutExternalLiterals()
        Creates a simplification of this constraint that is equal to it but for the absence of external literals. However, it is important to notice that, because the result is considered a simplification, it can only be used in contexts in which the original constraint (and therefore the external literals) hold, because it may still assume them to hold. While this may at first seem like an unnecessary restriction, it allows implementations to count on the external literal information to keep whatever internal bookkeeping that depends on the original constraint, avoiding the need to repeated computation.

        For example, equality constraints keep track of how many disequalities against uniquely named constants have been observed on the constraint's variable so far (even the disequalities that have been discarded since then). Copying this information to the new constraint is only justified if we know it is going to be used as a simplification of the original constraint, since it may not follow from the normalized atoms and external literals alone.

        Returns:

      • conjoin

        default SingleVariableConstraint conjoin(Expression formula,
                                         Context context)
        Description copied from interface: Constraint
        Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given formula, or null if they are contradictory.

        At this point, the formula should be either a literal, or a Constraint.

        Extensions may want to override this method if there are more efficient ways of conjoining with (certain types of) constraints than simply treating them as a formula

        Specified by:
        conjoin in interface Constraint
        Parameters:
        formula - the formula to be conjoined.
        context - the context
        Returns:
        the application result or null if contradiction.
